text: Hi I am still wondering about my question from Friday above.

"published action" means that the workflow itself is published

What this doc is saying is that you can setup a webhook testing service to show you the payload and how HubSpot will react to the action before you write the webhook code on your end.

You can do this before a workflow is published by using the "Test Action" button in the workflow UI
Answered in thread <@U04MZF2VA3H>

Are you sure? Because it really does not seem like they mean the workflow:
> By default, custom actions are created in an unpublished state. Unpublished custom actions are only visible in the developer portal associated with the corresponding HubSpot application.

Ah you're right. I understand I think.

Does the developer portal allow you to create workflows? I'm not at computer atm so can't check. If it does, and the unpublished custom actions don't appear there, that seems like a bug.

But they wouldn't be in test accounts, because those only have published items in them

Or, you should be able to. But I only found the test accounts at least.
hm yea that's super weird isn't it

because you're right that it seems that you should be able to do it from a test account given all of the context here
Yes, the custom action is created but in unpublished state.

The first time I tried this was the spring 2022.

Yes, that is very unclear. How would the request be triggered and sent to <http://webhook.site|webhook.site> if it is not part of a workflow?

Maybe they mean that you can test a published action in a dev portal (which would be dev-only anyways, because your dev app is running separate from production app).

And separately, you can use a <http://webhook.site|webhook.site> URL to help you "test" what HubSpot is going to send / receive from you
I think you would need to add it as a published action and then add it to a workflow in the test account

you should *always* use separate dev and production apps
That's independent of HubSpot

anyways, separate thing

and the HS KB is confusing and should be updated (if you have a way to communicate to HS that it's confusing.)

Yea, something is either confused or broken with `published` . I guess I can't help much further without actually trying it out myself.
```published: by default, custom actions are created in an unpublished state. Unpublished actions are only visible in the developer portal associated with your HubSpot application. To make a custom action visible to users, update the published flag on your action definition to true.```

If you have a separate dev/production app (which you said you do), then publishing in dev won't affect your production customers
If you have unpublished actions and they're not visible in test accounts, I agree something is confusing enough that there may be a bug or it's super not clear how to test them.
I know, but it defeats half the purpose of testing if I have to re-create it again for prod.
Our views of prod are different based on the last convo as well. Sorry I can't help any further.
I am not sure the purpose of published/unpublished, but it does say "only visible to the developer portal", which is true in this case.
Visible as in "can list through the API"?
I think that would be a fair interpretation of it.
(A fair but unfortunate interpretation based on the desire to test it)

Now this is hacky, but you could publish it, add it to a workflow in your test account, then unpublish it quickly. You're right that production customers would have access for the 10s or so in the meantime, but maybe that's acceptable

>  If an action is unpublished, portals that have already added the action to their workflow will still be able to edit and execute already added actions. But, they won't be able to add the action again.
Yes, it sure is visible. But if it is not possible to test the action before publishing, then the entire heading "Testing custom actions before publishing" is lying.
Depends on your definition of testing

> Before publishing your custom action, you can test action execution and fetching options by pointing the URL to <https://webhook.site/|webhook.site>. This allows you to inspect the payload and return a specific response.

I now interpret that to mean that you can "test" the webhook payload / response behavior without writing backend code (because otherwise you'd need to spend the time getting your server all setup and working)
But that's not "testing" the actual action. That's testing how HubSpot is going to execute / respond to an action
Is it possible that it will run a request to <http://webhooks.site|webhooks.site> at the time of creation?
